events.description: Called when an entity uses a nether or end portal. Cancel the event to prevent the entity from teleporting.
events.examples:
on entity portal:
	broadcast "A %type of event-entity% has entered a portal!

events.name: On Portal
events.description: Called when a player uses a nether or end portal. Cancel the event to prevent the player from teleporting.
events.examples: on player portal:

events.name: On Quit
events.description: Called when a player leaves the server.
events.examples:
on quit:
on disconnect:

events.name: On Respawn
events.description: Called when a player respawns. You should prefer this event over the death event as the player is technically alive when this event is called.
events.examples: on respawn:

events.name: On Teleport
events.description: Called whenever a player is teleported, either by a nether/end portal or other means (e.g. by plugins).
events.examples: on teleport:

events.name: On Sneak Toggle
events.description: Called when a player starts or stops sneaking. Use is sneaking to get whether the player was sneaking before the event was called.
events.examples:
# make players that stop sneaking jump
on sneak toggle:
	player is sneaking
	push the player upwards at speed 0.5

events.name: On Sprint Toggle
events.description: Called when a player starts or stops sprinting. Use is sprinting to get whether the player was sprinting before the event was called.
events.examples:
on sprint toggle:
	player is not sprinting
	send "Run!"

events.name: On Portal Create
events.description: Called when a portal is created, either by a player or mob lighting an obsidian frame on fire, or by a nether portal creating its teleportation target in the nether/overworld. In Minecraft 1.14+, you can use the player in this event. Please note that there may not always be a player (or other entity) in this event.
events.examples: on portal create:

events.name: On Projectile Hit
events.description: Called when a projectile hits an entity or a block. Use the damage event with a check for a projectile to be able to use the entity that got hit in the case when the projectile hit a living entity. A damage event will even be fired if the damage is 0, e.g. when throwing snowballs at non-nether mobs.
events.examples:
on projectile hit:
	event-projectile is arrow
	delete event-projectile

events.name: On Projectile Collide
events.description: Called when a projectile collides with an entity.
events.examples:
on projectile collide:
	teleport shooter of event-projectile to event-entity

events.name: On Shoot
events.description: Called whenever a projectile is shot. Use the shooter expression to get who shot the projectile.

events.name: On Sign Change
events.description: As signs are placed empty, this event is called when a player is done editing a sign.
events.examples:
on sign change:
	line 2 is empty
	set line 1 to "&amp;amp;amp;amp;lt;red&amp;amp;amp;amp;gt;%line 1%"

events.name: On Spawn Change
events.description: Called when the spawn point of a world changes.
events.examples:
on spawn change:
	broadcast "someone changed the spawn!"

events.name: On Vehicle Create
events.description: Called when a new vehicle is created, e.g. when a player places a boat or minecart.
events.examples: on vehicle create:

events.name: On Vehicle Damage
events.description: Called when a vehicle gets damage. Too much damage will destroy the vehicle.
events.examples: on vehicle damage:

events.name: On Vehicle Destroy
events.description: Called when a vehicle is destroyed. Any passenger will be ejected and the vehicle might drop some item(s).
events.examples:
on vehicle destroy:
	cancel event

events.name: On Vehicle Enter
events.description: Called when an entity enters a vehicle, either deliberately (players) or by falling into them (mobs).
events.examples:
on vehicle enter:
	entity is a player
	cancel event

events.name: On Vehicle Exit
events.description: Called when an entity exits a vehicle.

events.name: On Entity Mount
events.description: Called when entity starts riding another.
events.examples:
on mount:
	cancel event

events.name: On Entity Dismount
events.description: Called when an entity dismounts.
events.examples:
on dismount:
	kill event-entity

events.name: On World Init
events.description:
Called when a world is initialised. As all default worlds are initialised before any scripts are loaded, this event is only called for newly created worlds.
World management plugins might change the behaviour of this event though.
events.examples: on world init:

events.name: On World Load
events.description: Called when a world is loaded. As with the world init event, this event will not be called for the server's default world(s).
events.examples:
on world load:
	send "World is loading..." to console

events.name: On World Save
events.description: Called when a world is saved to disk. Usually all worlds are saved simultaneously, but world management plugins could change this.
events.examples:
on world saving:
	broadcast "World has been saved!"

events.name: On World Unload
events.description: Called when a world is unloaded. This event might never be called if you don't have a world management plugin.
events.examples:
on world unload:
	cancel event

events.name: On Gliding State Change
events.description: Called when an entity toggles glider on or off, or when server toggles gliding state of an entity forcibly.
events.examples:
on toggling gliding:
	cancel the event # bad idea, but you CAN do it!

events.name: On AoE Cloud Effect
events.description: Called when area effect cloud applies its potion effect. This happens every 5 ticks by default.
events.examples: on area cloud effect:

events.name: On Sheep Regrow Wool
events.description: Called when sheep regrows its sheared wool back.
events.examples:
on sheep grow wool:
	cancel event

events.name: On Inventory Open
events.description: Called when an inventory is opened for player.
events.examples:
on inventory open:
	close player's inventory

events.name: On Inventory Close
events.description: Called when player's currently viewed inventory is closed.

events.name: On Slime Split
events.description: Called when a slime splits. Usually this happens when a big slime dies.
events.examples: on slime split:

events.name: On Resurrect Attempt
events.description: Called when an entity dies, always. If they are not holding a totem, this is cancelled - you can, however, uncancel it.
events.examples:
on resurrect attempt:
	entity is player
	entity has permission "admin.undying"
	uncancel the event

events.name: On Player World Change
events.description: Called when a player enters a world. Does not work with other entities!
events.examples:
on player world change:
	world is "city"
	send "Welcome to the City!"

events.name: On Flight Toggle
events.description: Called when a players stops/starts flying.

events.name: On Language Change
events.description: Called after a player changed their language in the game settings. You can use the language expression to get the current language of the player. This event requires Minecraft 1.12+.

events.name: On Jump
events.description:
Called whenever a player jumps.
This event requires PaperSpigot.
events.examples:
on jump:
	event-player does not have permission "jump"
	cancel event

events.name: On Hand Item Swap
events.description:
Called whenever a player swaps the items in their main- and offhand slots.
Works also when one or both of the slots are empty.
The event is called before the items are actually swapped,
so when you use the player's tool or player's offtool expressions,
they will return the values before the swap -
this enables you to cancel the event before anything happens.
events.examples:
on swap hand items:
	event-player's tool is a diamond sword
	cancel event

events.name: On Server List Ping
events.description: Called when a server list ping is coming in, generally when a Minecraft client pings the server to show its information in the server list. The IP expression can be used to get the IP adress of the pinger. This event can be cancelled on PaperSpigot 1.12.2+ only and this means the player will see the server as offline (but still can join). Also you can use MOTD, Max Players, Online Players Count, Protocol Version, Version String, Hover List and Server Icon expressions, and Player Info Visibility and Hide Player from Server List effects to modify the server list.
events.examples:
on server list ping:
	set the motd to "Welcome %{player-by-IP::%ip%}%! Join now!" if {player-by-IP::%ip%} is set, else "Join now!"
	set the fake max players count to (online players count + 1)
	set the shown icon to a random server icon out of {server-icons::*}

events.name: On Swim Toggle
events.description: Called when an entity swims or stops swimming.
events.examples:
on swim toggle:
	event-entity does not have permission "swim"
	cancel event

events.name: On Riptide
events.description:
Called when the player activates the riptide enchantment, using their trident to propel them through the air.
Note: the riptide action is performed client side, so manipulating the player in this event may have undesired effects.
events.examples:
on riptide:
	send "You are riptiding!"

events.name: On Armor Change
events.description: Called when armor pieces of a player are changed.
events.examples:
on armor change:
	send "You equipped %event-item%!"

events.name: On Sponge Absorb
events.description: Called when a sponge absorbs blocks.
events.examples:
on sponge absorb:
	loop absorbed blocks:
		broadcast "%loop-block% was absorbed by a sponge"!

events.name: On Enchant Prepare
events.description: Called when a player puts an item into enchantment table. This event may be called multiple times. To get the enchant item, see the enchant item expression
events.examples:
on enchant prepare:
	set enchant offer 1 to sharpness 1
	set the cost of enchant offer 1 to 10 levels

events.name: On Enchant
events.description: Called when a player successfully enchants an item. To get the enchanted item, see the enchant item expression
events.examples:
on enchant:
	if the clicked button is 1: # offer 1
		set the applied enchantments to sharpness 10 and unbreaking 10

events.name: On Inventory Pickup
events.description: Called when an inventory (a hopper, a hopper minecart, etc.) picks up an item
events.examples: on inventory pickup:

events.name: On Horse Jump
events.description: Called when a horse jumps.
events.examples:
on horse jump:
	push event-entity upwards at speed 2

events.name: On Block Fertilize
events.description: Called when a player fertilizes blocks.
events.examples:
on block fertilize:
	send "Fertilized %size of fertilized blocks% blocks got fertilized."

events.name: On Arm Swing
events.description: Called when a player swings his arm.
events.examples:
on arm swing:
	send "You swung your arm!"

events.name: On Item Mend
events.description: Called when a player has an item repaired via the Mending enchantment.
events.examples:
on item mend:
	chance of 50%:
		cancel the event
		send "Oops! Mending failed!" to player

events.name: On Anvil Prepare
events.description: Called when an item is put in a slot for repair by an anvil. Please note that this event is called multiple times in a single item slot move.
events.examples:
on anvil prepare:
	event-item is set # result item
	chance of 5%:
		set repair cost to repair cost * 50%
		send "You're LUCKY! You got 50% discount." to player

events.name: On Player Trade
events.description: Called when a player has traded with a villager.
events.examples:
on player trade:
	chance of 50%:
		cancel event
		send "The trade was somehow denied!" to player

events.name: On Entity Jump
events.description: Called when an entity jumps.

events.name: On Anvil Damage
events.description:
Called when an anvil is damaged/broken from being used to repair/rename items.
Note: this does not include anvil damage from falling.
events.examples:
on anvil damage:
	cancel the event

events.name: On Inventory Slot Change
events.description:
Called when a slot in a player's inventory is changed.
Warning: setting the event-slot to a new item can result in an infinite loop.

events.name: On Chat
events.description: Called whenever a player chats. Use chat format to change message format. Use chat recipients to edit chat recipients.
events.examples:
on chat:
	if player has permission "owner":
		set chat format to "&amp;amp;amp;amp;lt;red&amp;amp;amp;amp;gt;[player]&amp;amp;amp;amp;lt;light gray&amp;amp;amp;amp;gt;: &amp;amp;amp;amp;lt;light red&amp;amp;amp;amp;gt;[message]"
	else if player has permission "admin":
		set chat format to "&amp;amp;amp;amp;lt;light red&amp;amp;amp;amp;gt;[player]&amp;amp;amp;amp;lt;light gray&amp;amp;amp;amp;gt;: &amp;amp;amp;amp;lt;orange&amp;amp;amp;amp;gt;[message]"
	else: #default message format
		set chat format to "&amp;amp;amp;amp;lt;orange&amp;amp;amp;amp;gt;[player]&amp;amp;amp;amp;lt;light gray&amp;amp;amp;amp;gt;: &amp;amp;amp;amp;lt;white&amp;amp;amp;amp;gt;[message]"

events.name: On Loot Generate
events.description:
Called when a loot table of an inventory is generated in the world.
For example, when opening a shipwreck chest.
events.examples:
on loot generate:
	chance of %10
	add 64 diamonds
	send "You hit the jackpot!!"

events.name: On Player Deep Sleep
events.description:
Called when a player has slept long enough to count as passing the night/storm.
Cancelling this event will prevent the player from being counted as deeply sleeping unless they exit and re-enter the bed.
events.examples:
on player deep sleeping:
	send "Zzzz.." to player

events.name: On Region Enter/Leave
events.description: Called when a player enters or leaves a region. This event requires a supported regions plugin to be installed.
events.examples:
on region exit:
	message "Leaving %region%."

events.name: On Test Case
events.description: Contents represent one test case.

classes.name: Boolean
classes.description: A boolean is a value that is either true or false. Other accepted names are 'on' and 'yes' for true, and 'off' and 'no' for false.
classes.examples: set {config.%player%.use mod} to false

classes.name: Text
classes.description: Text is simply text, i.e. a sequence of characters, which can optionally contain expressions which will be replaced with a meaningful representation (e.g. %player% will be replaced with the player's name). Because scripts are also text, you have to put text into double quotes to tell Skript which part of the line is an effect/expression and which part is the text. Please read the article on Texts and Variable Names to learn more.
classes.examples:
broadcast "Hello World!"
message "Hello %player%"
message "The id of ""%type of tool%"" is %id of tool%."

classes.name: Weather Type
classes.description: The weather types sunny, rainy, and thundering.
classes.examples:
is raining
is sunny in the player's world
message "It is %weather in the argument's world% in %world of the argument%"

classes.name: Time
classes.description: A time is a point in a minecraft day's time (i.e. ranges from 0:00 to 23:59), which can vary per world. See date and timespan for the other time types of Skript.
classes.examples:
at 20:00:
	time is 8 pm
	broadcast "It's %time%"

classes.name: Timeperiod
classes.description: A period of time between two times. Mostly useful since you can use this to test for whether it's day, night, dusk or dawn in a specific world. This type might be removed in the future as you can use 'time of world is between x and y' as a replacement.
classes.examples: time in world is night

classes.name: Date
classes.description: A date is a certain point in the real world's time which can be obtained with now expression, unix date expression and date function. See time and timespan for the other time types of Skript.

classes.name: Direction
classes.description: A direction, e.g. north, east, behind, 5 south east, 1.3 meters to the right, etc. Locations and some blocks also have a direction, but without a length. Please note that directions have changed extensively in the betas and might not work perfectly. They can also not be used as command arguments.
classes.examples:
set the block below the victim to a chest
loop blocks from the block infront of the player to the block 10 below the player:
	set the block behind the loop-block to water

classes.name: Inventory Slot
classes.description: Represents a single slot of an inventory. Notable slots are the armour slots and furnace slots. The most important property that distinguishes a slot from an item is its ability to be changed, e.g. it can be set, deleted, enchanted, etc. (Some item expressions can be changed as well, e.g. items stored in variables. For that matter: slots are never saved to variables, only the items they represent at the time when the variable is set). Please note that tool can be regarded a slot, but it can actually change it's position, i.e. doesn't represent always the same slot.
classes.examples:
set tool of player to dirt
delete helmet of the victim
set the color of the player's tool to green
enchant the player's chestplate with projectile protection 5

classes.name: Color
classes.description: Wool, dye and chat colors.
classes.examples:
color of the sheep is red or black
set the color of the block to green
message "You're holding a &amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;lt;%color of tool%&amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;gt;%color of tool%&amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;lt;reset&amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;gt; wool block"
patterns: black, dark grey/dark gray, grey/light grey/gray/light gray/silver, white, blue/dark blue, cyan/aqua/dark cyan/dark aqua, light blue/light cyan/light aqua, green/dark green, light green/lime/lime green, yellow/light yellow, orange/gold/dark yellow, red/dark red, pink/light red, purple/dark purple, magenta/light purple, brown/indigo

classes.name: Tree Type
classes.description: A tree type represents a tree species or a huge mushroom species. These can be generated in a world with the generate tree effect.
classes.examples:
grow any regular tree at the block
grow a huge red mushroom above the block
patterns: [any] <general tree/mushroom type>, e.g. tree/any jungle tree/etc.

classes.name: Player
classes.description:
A player. Depending on whether a player is online or offline several actions can be performed with them, though you won't get any errors when using effects that only work if the player is online (e.g. changing their inventory) on an offline player.
You have two possibilities to use players as command arguments: <player> and <offline player>. The first requires that the player is online and also accepts only part of the name, while the latter doesn't require that the player is online, but the player's name has to be entered exactly.

classes.name: Offline Player
classes.description: A player that is possibly offline. See player for more information. Please note that while all effects and conditions that require a player can be used with an offline player as well, they will not work if the player is not actually online.

classes.description: Represents the environment of a world.

classes.name: Moon Phase
classes.description: Represents the phase of a moon.

classes.name: Region
classes.description:
A region of a regions plugin. Skript currently supports WorldGuard, Factions, GriefPrevention and PreciousStones.
Please note that some regions plugins do not have named regions, some use numerical ids to identify regions, and some may have regions with the same name in different worlds, thus using regions like "region name" in scripts may or may not work.

classes.name: Money
classes.description: A certain amount of money. Please note that this differs from numbers as it includes a currency symbol or name, but usually the two are interchangeable, e.g. you can both add 100$ to the player's balance and add 100 to the player's balance.
classes.examples:
add 10£ to the player's account
remove Fr. 9.95 from the player's money
set the victim's money to 0
increase the attacker's balance by the level of the victim * 100
patterns: <number> $ or $ <number>, where '$' is your server's currency, e.g. '10 rupees' or '£5.00'

classes.name: Timespan
classes.description: A timespan is a difference of two different dates or times, e.g '10 minutes'. Timespans are always displayed as real life time, but can be defined as minecraft time, e.g. '5 minecraft days and 12 hours'. NOTE: Months always have the value of 30 days, and years of 365 days. See date and time for the other time types of Skript.
classes.examples:
every 5 minecraft days:
	wait a minecraft second and 5 ticks
every 10 mc days and 12 hours:
	halt for 12.7 irl minutes, 12 hours and 120.5 seconds

classes.name: Enchantment Type
classes.description: An enchantment with an optional level, e.g. 'sharpness 2' or 'fortune'.
classes.examples:
enchant the player's tool with sharpness 5
helmet is enchanted with waterbreathing

classes.name: Living Entity
classes.description: A living entity, i.e. a mob or player, not inanimate entities like projectiles or dropped items.
classes.examples:
spawn 5 powered creepers
shoot a zombie from the creeper
patterns: see entity, but ignore inanimate objects

classes.name: Number
classes.description:
A number, e.g. 2.5, 3, or -9812454.
Please note that many expressions only need integers, i.e. will discard any fractional parts of any numbers without producing an error.
classes.examples:
set the player's health to 5.5
set {_temp} to 2*{_temp} - 2.5
patterns: [-]###[.###] (any amount of digits; very large numbers will be truncated though)

classes.name: Item Type
classes.description: An item type is an alias, e.g. 'a pickaxe', 'all plants', etc., and can result in different items when added to an inventory, and unlike items they are well suited for checking whether an inventory contains a certain item or whether a certain item is of a certain type. An item type can also have one or more enchantments with or without a specific level defined, and can optionally start with 'all' or 'every' to make this item type represent all types that the alias represents, including data ranges.
classes.examples:
give 4 torches to the player
add all slabs to the inventory of the block
player's tool is a diamond sword of sharpness
remove a pickaxes of fortune 4 from {stored items::*}
set {_item} to 10 of every upside-down stair
block is dirt or farmland

classes.name: Entity
classes.description: An entity is something in a world that's not a block, e.g. a player, a skeleton, or a zombie, but also projectiles like arrows, fireballs or thrown potions, or special entities like dropped items, falling blocks or paintings.
classes.examples:
entity is a zombie or creeper
player is an op
projectile is an arrow
shoot a fireball from the player
patterns: player, op, wolf, tamed ocelot, powered creeper, zombie, unsaddled pig, fireball, arrow, dropped item, item frame, etc.

classes.name: Block Data
classes.description: Block data is the detailed information about a block, referred to in Minecraft as BlockStates, allowing for the manipulation of different aspects of the block, including shape, waterlogging, direction the block is facing, and so much more. Information regarding each block's optional data can be found on Minecraft's Wiki. Find the block you're looking for and scroll down to 'Block States'. Different states must be separated by a semicolon (see examples). The 'minecraft:' namespace is optional, as well as are underscores.
classes.examples:
set block at player to campfire[lit=false]
set target block of player to oak stairs[facing=north;waterlogged=true]
set block at player to grass_block[snowy=true]
set loop-block to minecraft:chest[facing=north]
set block above player to oak_log[axis=y]
set target block of player to minecraft:oak_leaves[distance=2;persistent=false]

classes.name: Command Sender
classes.description: A player or the console.
classes.examples:
command /push [&amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;lt;player&amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;gt;]:
	trigger:
		if arg-1 is not set:
			if command sender is console:
				send "You can't push yourself as a console :\" to sender
				stop
			push sender upwards with force 2
			send "Yay!"
		else:
			push arg-1 upwards with force 2
			send "Yay!" to sender and arg-1
patterns: use the console for the console

classes.name: Item
classes.description: An item, e.g. a stack of torches, a furnace, or a wooden sword of sharpness 2. Unlike item type an item can only represent exactly one item (e.g. an upside-down cobblestone stair facing west), while an item type can represent a whole range of items (e.g. any cobble stone stairs regardless of direction). You don't usually need this type except when you want to make a command that only accepts an exact item. Please note that currently 'material' is exactly the same as 'item', i.e. can have an amount & enchantments.
classes.examples:
set {_item} to type of the targeted block
{_item} is a torch
patterns: [<number> [of]] <alias> [of <enchantment> <level>], Where <alias> must be an alias that represents exactly one item (i.e cannot be a general alias like 'sword' or 'plant')

classes.name: Metadata Holder
classes.description: Something that can hold metadata (e.g. an entity or block)
classes.examples: set metadata value "super cool" of player to true

classes.name: Entity Type
classes.description: The type of an entity, e.g. player, wolf, powered creeper, etc.
classes.examples:
victim is a cow
spawn a creeper

classes.name: Entity Type with Amount
classes.description: An entity type with an amount, e.g. '2 zombies'. I might remove this type in the future and make a more general 'type' type, i.e. a type that has a number and a type.
classes.examples: spawn 5 creepers behind the player

classes.name: Type
classes.description:
Represents a type, e.g. number, object, item type, location, block, world, entity type, etc.
This is mostly used for expressions like 'event-<type>', '<type>-argument', 'loop-<type>', etc., e.g. event-world, number-argument and loop-player.
classes.examples:
{variable} is a number # check whether the variable contains a number, e.g. -1 or 5.5
{variable} is a type # check whether the variable contains a type, e.g. number or player
{variable} is an object # will always succeed if the variable is set as everything is an object, even types.
disable PvP in the event-world
kill the loop-entity
patterns: See the type name patterns of all types - including this one

classes.name: Damage Cause
classes.description: The cause/type of a damage event, e.g. lava, fall, fire, drowning, explosion, poison, etc. Please note that support for this type is very rudimentary, e.g. lava, fire and burning, as well as projectile and attack are considered different types.

classes.name: Object
classes.description: The supertype of all types, meaning that if %object% is used in e.g. a condition it will accept all kinds of expressions.

structures.name: Aliases
structures.description: Used for registering custom aliases for a script.
structures.examples:
aliases:
	blacklisted items = TNT, bedrock, obsidian, mob spawner, lava, lava bucket
	shiny swords = gold sword, iron sword, diamond sword

structures.name: Command
structures.examples:
command /broadcast <string>:
	usage: A command for broadcasting a message to all players.
	permission: skript.command.broadcast
	permission message: You don't have permission to broadcast messages
	aliases: /bc
	executable by: players and console
	cooldown: 15 seconds
	cooldown message: You last broadcast a message %elapsed time% ago. You can broadcast another message in %remaining time%.
	cooldown bypass: skript.command.broadcast.admin
	cooldown storage: {cooldown::%player%}
	trigger:
		broadcast the argument

structures.name: Function
structures.description:
Functions are structures that can be executed with arguments/parameters to run code.
They can also return a value to the trigger that is executing the function.
Note that local functions come before global functions execution
structures.examples:
function sayMessage(message: text):
	broadcast {_message} # our message argument is available in '{_message}'

local function giveApple(amount: number) :: item:
	return {_amount} of apple

structures.name: Options
structures.description:
Options are used for replacing parts of a script with something else.
For example, an option may represent a message that appears in multiple locations.
Take a look at the example below that showcases this.
structures.examples:
options:
	no_permission: You're missing the required permission to execute this command!

command /ping:
	permission: command.ping
	permission message: {@no_permission}
	trigger:
		message "Pong!"

command /pong:
	permission: command.pong
	permission message: {@no_permission}
	trigger:
		message "Ping!"

structures.name: Variables
structures.description:
Used for defining variables present within a script.
This section is not required, but it ensures that a variable has a value if it doesn't exist when the script is loaded.
structures.examples:
variables:
	{joins} = 0
	{balance::%player%} = 0

on join:
	add 1 to {joins}
	message "Your balance is %{balance::%player%}%"

functions.name: floor
functions.description: Rounds a number down, i.e. returns the closest integer smaller than or equal to the argument.

functions.name: asin
functions.description: The inverse of the sine, also called arcsin. Returns result in degrees, not radians. Only returns values from -90 to 90.

functions.name: caseEquals
functions.description: Checks if the contents of a list of strings are strictly equal with case sensitivity.
functions.examples:
caseEquals("hi", "Hi") = false
caseEquals("text", "text", "text") = true
caseEquals({some list variable::*})

functions.name: tan
functions.description: The tangent function. This is basically sin(arg)/cos(arg). Uses degrees, not radians.

functions.name: world
functions.description: Gets a world from its name.

functions.name: mod
functions.description: Returns the modulo of the given arguments, i.e. the remainder of the division d/m, where d and m are the arguments of this function. The returned value is always positive. Returns NaN (not a number) if the second argument is zero.

functions.name: log
functions.description: A logarithm, with base 10 if none is specified. This is the inverse operation to exponentiation (for positive bases only), i.e. log(base ^ exponent, base) = exponent for any positive number 'base' and any number 'exponent'. Another useful equation is base ^ log(a, base) = a for any numbers 'base' and 'a'. Please note that due to how numbers are represented in computers, these equations do not hold for all numbers, as the computed values may slightly differ from the correct value. Returns NaN (not a number) if any of the arguments are negative.

functions.name: location
functions.description:
Creates a location from a world and 3 coordinates, with an optional yaw and pitch.
If for whatever reason the world is not found, it will fallback to the server's main world.
functions.examples:
location(0, 128, 0)
location(player's x-coordinate, player's y-coordinate + 5, player's z-coordinate, player's world, 0, 90)
location(0, 64, 0, world "world_nether")
location(100, 110, -145, world("my_custom_world"))
patterns: location(x: number, y: number, z: number, world: world = event-world, yaw: number = [[integer:0]], pitch: number = [[integer:0]])

functions.name: ceiling
functions.description: Alias of ceil.

functions.name: product
functions.description: Calculates the product of a list of numbers.
functions.examples:
product(1) = 1
product(2, 3, 4) = 24
product({some list variable::*})
product(2, {_v::*}, and the player's y-coordinate)

functions.name: sin
functions.description: The sine function. It starts at 0° with a value of 0, goes to 1 at 90°, back to 0 at 180°, to -1 at 270° and then repeats every 360°. Uses degrees, not radians.

functions.name: min
functions.description: Returns the minimum number from a list of numbers.

functions.name: abs
functions.description: Returns the absolute value of the argument, i.e. makes the argument positive.

functions.name: sum
functions.description: Sums a list of numbers.
functions.examples:
sum(1) = 1
sum(2, 3, 4) = 9
sum({some list variable::*})
sum(2, {_v::*}, and the player's y-coordinate)

functions.name: rgb
functions.description: Returns a RGB color from the given red, green and blue parameters.
patterns: rgb(red: long, green: long, blue: long)

functions.name: round
functions.description: Rounds a number, i.e. returns the closest integer to the argument. Place a second argument to define the decimal placement.

functions.name: sqrt
functions.description: The square root, which is the inverse operation to squaring a number (for positive numbers only). This is the same as (argument) ^ (1/2) – other roots can be calculated via number ^ (1/root), e.g. set {_l} to {_volume}^(1/3). Returns NaN (not a number) if the argument is negative.

functions.name: calcExperience
functions.description: Calculates the total amount of experience needed to achieve given level from scratch in Minecraft.

functions.name: exp
functions.description: The exponential function. You probably don't need this if you don't know what this is.

functions.name: atan
functions.description: The inverse of the tangent, also called arctan. Returns result in degrees, not radians. Only returns values from -90 to 90.

functions.name: max
functions.description: Returns the maximum number from a list of numbers.

functions.name: cos
functions.description: The cosine function. This is basically the sine shifted by 90°, i.e. cos(a) = sin(a + 90°), for any number a. Uses degrees, not radians.

functions.name: atan2
functions.description: Similar to atan, but requires two coordinates and returns values from -180 to 180. The returned angle is measured counterclockwise in a standard mathematical coordinate system (x to the right, y to the top).

functions.name: ceil
functions.description: Rounds a number up, i.e. returns the closest integer larger than or equal to the argument.

functions.name: date
functions.description:
Creates a date from a year, month, and day, and optionally also from hour, minute, second and millisecond.
A time zone and DST offset can be specified as well (in minutes), if they are left out the server's time zone and DST offset are used (the created date will not retain this information).
functions.examples:
date(2014, 10, 1) # 0:00, 1st October 2014
date(1990, 3, 5, 14, 30) # 14:30, 5th May 1990
date(1999, 12, 31, 23, 59, 59, 999, -3*60, 0) # almost year 2000 in parts of Brazil (-3 hours offset, no DST)
patterns: date(year: number, month: number, day: number, hour: number = [[integer:0]], minute: number = [[integer:0]], second: number = [[integer:0]], millisecond: number = [[integer:0]], zone_offset: number = [[double:NaN]], dst_offset: number = [[double:NaN]])

functions.name: ln
functions.description:
The natural logarithm. You probably don't need this if you don't know what this is.
Returns NaN (not a number) if the argument is negative.

functions.name: acos
functions.description: The inverse of the cosine, also called arccos. Returns result in degrees, not radians. Only returns values from 0 to 180.

functions.name: vector
functions.description: Creates a new vector, which can be used with various expressions, effects and functions.
patterns: vector(x: number, y: number, z: number)
